# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 165, 905, 260]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 278, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 310, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 326, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 564, 103]]<|/det|>
Given that \(y = 6x\cos \left(x^{2} + 1\right)\), find an expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Use logarithms to solve the inequality \(4^{x} < 0.05\). Give your answer in the form \(x < a\), where the value of \(a\) is correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 917, 357]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 148, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 370, 425, 388]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(\left|3x + 8\right| < 9\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 917, 761]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 146, 790]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 772, 772, 790]]<|/det|>
Hence state the integers that satisfy both of the inequalities in parts (a) and (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 772, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 803, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 146, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
Sketch, on a single diagram, the graphs of \(y = 3\mathrm{e}^{- 2x}\) and \(y = \sec x\) for values of \(x\) such that \(0 \leqslant x < \frac{1}{2}\pi\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 146, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of the point of intersection of the two graphs satisfies the equation \(x = \frac{1}{2}\ln (3\cos x)\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 653, 144, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 653, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in part **(b)**, to find the \(x\)-coordinate of the point of intersection correct to 3 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 5 decimal places. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 87, 603, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 260, 917, 293]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = 6\mathrm{e}^{2x} - \mathrm{e}^{3x}\) . The shaded region is bounded by the axes and the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 146, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 552, 325]]<|/det|>
Find the exact \(x\)-coordinate of the maximum point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 308, 917, 325]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 336, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 148, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region. Give your answer in the form \(\frac{p}{q}\) , where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers. [4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 123, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 390, 92]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 103, 608, 123]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} + bx^{2} - ax - 24,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 918, 170]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((2x - 3)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and that the remainder is \(-15\) when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 183, 148, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 368, 201]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 413, 90]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 101, 918, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 508, 144, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 650, 526]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\mathrm{p}(3\cos \mathrm{e}\mathrm{\Theta}) = 0\) for \(90^{\circ} < \mathrm{\Theta} < 270^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 507, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 430, 88]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 110, 626, 140]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{2t + 1}{3t + 4}, \qquad y = 2\ln (3t + 4),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 160, 240, 185]]<|/det|>
where \(t > -\frac{4}{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 199, 146, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 918, 225]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) can be expressed in the form \(c(3t + 4)\) and state the value of the constant \(c\). [5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 240, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 682, 91]]<|/det|>
It is given that the gradient of the curve at the point \((a, \ln 100)\) is \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 369, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 918, 726]]<|/det|>
State whether the curve represents a decreasing function or an increasing function or neither. Give a reason for your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 707, 918, 726]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 494, 94]]<|/det|>
Prove that \(\sin^2 2x + 4\cos^2 x\cos 2x \equiv 4\cos^4 x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 75, 920, 95]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 106, 917, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 572, 148, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 572, 705, 590]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of the constant \(k\) for which the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 602, 618, 621]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}2x + 4\cos^{2}x\cos 2x + 5 = k\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 324, 651]]<|/det|>
has no real solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 634, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 664, 917, 935]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 85, 144, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 591, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\int_{-\frac{1}{3}\pi}^{\frac{1}{3}\pi} \sqrt{\sin^2 t + 4 \cos^2\left(\frac{1}{2}t\right)} \cos t \, \mathrm{d}t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 83, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 123, 917, 952]]<|/det|>
